ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned many new skills, from coding using new libraries to creating and analyzing human subject tests.
I had the opportunity to apply what I learned over my undergraduate career to an extended and self-guided project in computer science. I sharpened my ability to research, document, and implement.
I gained a deeper understanding of the process of researching and writing a CS paper, as well as specific expertise in formal security proofs.
This course is obviously different for everyone. However, I enjoyed the flexibility in being able to choose a topic I wanted to further explore.
I worked on a semester-long senior project, consisting of my codebase and my thesis-style paper.
I learned about container orchestration, IP addressing and networks, and Python hardware control. I gained many skills in reading documentation
You will learn how to take a concept that you find interesting, do research, and built it from the ground up.
I learned ArcGIS Pro!
Devising a research question, Modifying a large codebase and contributing to an open source project, different python libraries and algorithms, q learning, game theory.

I continued some CS research I had been doing with a professor as a 290, and I was able to dive quite deeply into the research and came up with a pretty cool, novel method for solving the problem at hand.
I learned to work with a development team on a web application.

I learnt to build my own projects and find my own ideas for projects. I learnt persistence, and how to push through a difficult project that may not have been done before or have a clear answer. I got to work with a fantastic professor, which is really a unique experience. And I wrote my first research-style paper, so I know how to do it in the future.
I gained insights into R, building R packages, and medical concepts relating to the human immune system.
Learn to design and work on a personal project, learn to do research and self-learning
Learned Java and how to use Android Studio, how to use Google ML Kit

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very supportive department with many great resources.

The extreme self-guided nature of the course is both a strength and a drawback. I interacted with my advisor only six times, for only about 15 minutes each, every meeting serving only to provide a few suggestion for novel directions to explore and general confirmation that I was on the right track and going at the right pace. This allows students to build their ability to self-direct. I personally found this very challenging, but a great learning experience. As I gather, increased structure is being added to the course starting next semester, so this will not be as true anymore.
so little guidance. very confusing, hard to pick a project and an advisor
We were able to explore our own research interests. Having more informal check-ins might be nice for the future to keep everyone on-track.

I would consider it a weakness how disorganized this course ran. Anything that went positively is due to my adviser and I setting up meetings/setting the course for the project, because otherwise there was no structure enforced by the DUS/course. Communications from the DUS were sparse, and it's frustrating that only recently a timeline for runs of CS490 was drafted via the cs-majors panlist. I'm happy there are changes coming, but it would have been great to have more sense of community and departmental support this semester. It's disappointing that friends in other majors had colloquia/poster presentations to invite their friends to at the end of the semester, meanwhile there's not much to show that I completed the CS major, nor was there much acknowledgement/celebration from the department.

There was not much guidance on how to select a project or advisor, and no official guidance or check-ins from the department throughout the semester until it was time to hand in the projects. One of the strengths is being able to participate in independent research/create your own project, but it could have more structure.

Strengths - it's not like a black box where all of a sudden you have to turn it in. The CS faculty sets deadlines at certain periods so you're able to stay on top of your work. Additionally, the CS student board will hold work sessions to help you stay on top of your work.

It was a really cool experience to work on my project with Dr Blenman my advisor. 

I think that this course needs to have more interaction with its student in terms of sending more updates on canvas and announcements. 

Additionally, it would be great there was more help explaining the senior project at the end of junior year and projects that students can do or get involved with
The strength of the course is heavily dependent on the advisor's involvement. Luckily my advisor was very helpful and was willing to take the time to answer my questions and address my concerns.
More formally required meetings with staff would be very helpful.

The idea of a project is a great, especially at the end of my time at Yale. However, there isn't a lot of organization or structure - the deadlines aren't particularly well advertised (you have to go on the cpsc 490 website), and it would be helpful if they gave you some sort of timeline with precise dates rather than "third thursday of classes" or "end of reading period". This is similar for the process of finding an advisor - I think I was lucky to have started thinking about it early.
The independent structure of the course made it possible to curve my timeline in a way that worked best for me and my advisor.

Feel like it could be more structured in terms of resources, i think the course was a bit unstructured and open ended, and perhaps some optional structure could support continuity. Also I feel that there werent many resources or support, especially if you create your own project. In my opinion, there should be resources and a space for CS students to work on projects and encourage collaboration and promote students teaching each other

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it is not only a requirement for CS majors but also a great opportunity to have fun creating your own project.
If you are interested in this course, you probably have to take it to graduate.
Obviously this is required for CPSC majors. If non-majors can also take it, I would recommend it if a student wants credit for a project they want to do with an advisor.
Yes!
It's required for a CS major. I'm not even sure you can take this class as a non-CS-senior.
Its required to graduate
You need to take this for your senior project. However, I would recommend to take if there's a field you want to learn more about / have an interesting idea you want to explore further.
Yes
A thesis is a great way to kickstart research for future degrees or even build relationship with faculty. It is something you fully have to commit to but it is quite formative.
Yes, this is a requirement, and also a fantastic use of time.
Yes!
Yes, you also need this to graduate. But its a good way to get class credit while working on a personal project
Required for CS majors!
Extremely hard to reach by email. changes dynamic of course quite substantially
